title: Boris Johnson facing failure in December general election bid
text:
Boris Johnson is likely to fail in his bid to get MPs to approve a 12 December election today (Picture: PA)

MPs will vote today on whether they back Boris Johnson’s call for a 12 December general election.

The prime minister needs the backing of two-thirds of MPs – 434 – to succeed under the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act (FTPA).

Crucially, it means he needs the support of opposition parties and Labour has already voiced its lack of support for the early election.

Leader Jeremy Corbyn called for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit to be taken ‘completely off the table’ before he could support sending the UK to the polls.

But the Liberal Democrats and Scottish National Party yesterday offered Mr Johnson a way out of the deadlock.

Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson and the SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford put forward a tightly-drafted Bill that would grant an election on 9 December – three days earlier than the PM’s suggested polling date – as long as the European Union grant a Brexit extension until 31 January.

The draft law, currently scheduled for Tuesday’s sitting, would require a simple majority of 320 MPs to support it in order to dissolve Parliament – 114 fewer than under the FTPA ‘super majority’ rules.

That means the SNP-Lib Dem Bill is likely to pass even without Labour backing.

Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson has joined with the SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford to draft a Bill for a 9 December election (Picture: PA)

Downing Street indicated it could be willing to support the pro-Remain parties’ proposals in a possible compromise offer.

A Number 10 source said if the Government’s request for an election was lost, ‘we will look at all options to get Brexit done including ideas similar to that proposed by other opposition parties’.

If passed on Tuesday, the SNP-Lib Dem Bill is likely to achieve Royal Assent by Thursday and Parliament would be dissolved by the end of the week for the first December poll in almost a century.

Its quick dissolution turnaround period would mean the Withdrawal Agreement Bill – the attempt to put Mr Johnson’s Brexit deal with the EU into law – would fail to pass before Thursday, the Halloween Brexit date.

Mr Johnson once said he would rather be ‘dead in a ditch’ than miss the 31 October deadline.

Meanwhile, EU leaders are meeting in Brussels today to thrash out their decision on a Brexit extension.

A leaked paper seen by the Guardian suggested the EU has agreed to Britain’s request for an extension until 31 January.

European Council President Donald Tusk has been in talks with EU leaders over the weekend before ambassadors for the 27 member states meet this morning.

A deceleration attached to the paper says the bloc is not prepared to renegotiate the withdrawal deal.
